newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian call money eases on poor demand for funds.
newsitem.headline: Indian call money eases on poor demand for funds.

text.p: Indian call money rates fell sharply on Wednesday, ending in the 2.0-3.0 percent range on lack of demand for funds, dealers said.
Call money fell after opening the day in the 5.0-7.0 percent range.
Rates have come down from the 9.0-10.0 percent levels on Monday, dealers said.
Dealers said there was little demand for funds as most banks seemed to have covered their positions ahead of the reporting Friday on August 30.
"Lenders were chasing borrowers today," a dealer at a foreign bank said. "There was little demand for funds."
Security prices firmed up marginally in the secondary market as low call money rates led to buying interest, dealers said.
Treasury bills maturing in mid-September were traded at yields between 7.50-7.70 percent, down from Tuesday's nine percent levels, dealers said.
The 364-day treasury bill maturing on July 18, 1997 was traded at a yield of 12.70 percent against Tuesday's 12.85.
Securities with a one-year maturity were traded at a yield of 13.06 percent against 13.20 on Tuesday while two-year securities were traded at 13.40 percent against 13.57 percent, dealers said.
No trades were reported in certificates of deposits or commercial paper.
